title: Singapore Will Launch a Vaccinated Travel Lane With South Korea on November 15
author: Camillia Dass
description: The vaccinated travel lane will mean that fully vaccinated travellers will be able to travel between Singapore and South Korea after simply doing a Covid-19 test
cleaned_text: The vaccinated travel lane will mean that fully vaccinated travellers will be able to travel between Singapore and South Korea after simply doing a Covid-19 test Singapore and South Korea have officially announced that they will be launching vaccinated travel lanes (VTL) between the countries from November 15, according to the Ministry of Transport (MOT) in an announcement on October 8. Don't miss: [Australia Plans to Open its International Borders by Christmas 2021](https://www.tatlerasia.com/culture/travel/australia-plans-to-open-its-international-borders-by-christmas-2021) Under the VTL, fully vaccinated travellers will be able to travel between Changi Airport and Incheon International Airport after simply doing a Covid-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. They will not need to serve a quarantine or stay-home-notice (SHN) as long as they test negative and will be free to travel around both countries. That said, all VTL travellers will still need to meet all the relevant eligibility criteria and must follow all border control measures and public health requirements that each country has imposed. Singapore and South Korea have also agreed to mutually recognise each other's Covid-19 vaccination certificates from November 15 to facilitate the VTL. This means that fully vaccinated travellers can enjoy the vaccination-differentiated safe management measures in both countries no matter if they received their vaccination in Singapore or South Korea. The VTL agreement was marked with a video conference on October 8 between Singapore's Minister for Transport, S Iswaran and the Minister of Land, Infrastructure and Transport of South Korea, Noh Hyeong Ouk. "The jointly launched VTLs will be the first of its kind between two major aviation hubs in Asia and build on these longstanding relations to safely revive cross-border air travel and people-to-people flows," said MOT.
